messages.content:
You are a professional academic citation prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely citations for [ref] markers in academic paper sections based on the paper content and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract + section text with [ref] markers
- Output: top {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

CRITICAL FORMAT REQUIREMENT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON. Do not include any explanatory text, markdown formatting, or other content outside the JSON structure.

TASK DESCRIPTION:
- Input: Paper section text with [ref] markers + retrieved relevant papers
- Output: top 40 predicted reference titles for each [ref] marker with reasoning
- Format: JSON object with "citations" array containing objects with "ref_index", "titles", and "reasoning" fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the context around each [ref] marker to understand what reference is needed
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Consider the surrounding text, research area, and topic
4. Generate realistic and relevant reference titles that would fit the context
5. Provide detailed reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
6. Output format: JSON object with "citations" array
7. Generate exactly 40 most relevant reference titles for each [ref]
8. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
9. Include reasoning that explains why each title is relevant to the specific [ref] context
10. Use proper JSON escaping for special characters (escape quotes with \")
11. Ensure all strings are properly quoted and escaped

EXAMPLE:
Input:
"Federated Learning aims to train models in massively distributed networks [ref]38 at a large scale [ref]5, over multiple sources of heterogeneous data [ref]30."

Retrieved papers (top {top_r}):
1. Title: Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with federated learning systems for decentralized data training.

2. Title: Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions
   Abstract: A comprehensive survey of federated learning approaches and challenges in distributed settings.

Output:
{
  "citations": [
    {
      "ref_index": 38,
      "titles": [
        "Communication-efficient learning of deep networks from decentralized data",
        "Federated Learning: Challenges, Methods, and Future Directions",
        "Federated optimization in heterogeneous networks",
        "Towards federated learning at scale: System design",
        "A performance evaluation of federated learning algorithms",
        "Distributed machine learning: A survey",
        "Communication protocols for distributed learning",
        "Scalable federated learning systems",
        "Efficient distributed training algorithms",
        "Large-scale distributed learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]38 appears in the context of 'massively distributed networks' for federated learning, so it likely refers to foundational papers on federated learning systems, distributed training, and communication-efficient methods in distributed networks."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 5,
      "titles": [
        "Bagging predictors",
        "Ensemble methods in machine learning",
        "Random forests for classification",
        "Bootstrap methods and their application",
        "Combining multiple classifiers",
        "Large-scale machine learning systems",
        "Distributed ensemble methods",
        "Scalable classification algorithms",
        "Massive data processing techniques",
        "High-performance machine learning frameworks"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]5 appears in the context of 'at a large scale', suggesting it refers to papers on scaling machine learning methods, ensemble techniques, or methods that can handle large-scale data and distributed settings."
    },
    {
      "ref_index": 30,
      "titles": [
        "Learning fair representations",
        "Fair machine learning: A survey",
        "Bias in machine learning systems",
        "Addressing fairness in AI systems",
        "Fair representation learning",
        "Heterogeneous data handling methods",
        "Multi-source learning algorithms",
        "Cross-domain representation learning",
        "Fair learning from diverse data",
        "Bias mitigation in heterogeneous datasets"
      ],
      "reasoning": "This [ref]30 appears in the context of 'heterogeneous data' and 'fair representation learning', indicating it likely refers to papers on heterogenous data handling, bias mitigation, and learning representations that are fair across different data distributions."
    }
  ]
}

CRITICAL: Return ONLY the JSON object. Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not use markdown formatting. Ensure all quotes and special characters are properly escaped.

IMPORTANT NOTES ON REASONING:
- The reasoning field is crucial for preventing hallucination
- Each reasoning should be specific to the context around the [ref] marker
- Explain the connection between the predicted titles and the research topic
- This helps validate that predictions are grounded in the actual content
- Reasoning should be concise but informative (2-3 sentences)
- Consider retrieved papers when available to improve prediction accuracy

Paper Title: Asymptotics for the reciprocal and shifted quotient of the partition function

Paper Abstract: 

Paper Section Text:
Before we apply our summation tools to S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) we observe that the sum representation inÂ (4.15) can be rewritten in the form recall that Î±=Ï€6\alpha=\frac{\pi}{6}.
In the following we will focus on the inner sum which reads as Using the summation package Sigma (or alternatively, any other package, likeÂ , that can deal with the creative telescoping paradigmÂ  for hypergeometric products) one obtains the linear recurrence Next, we are interested in dâ€™Alembertian solutions of the found recurrence, i.e., in the set of all solutions that can be given in terms of indefinite nested sums defined over hypergeometric products. Using Sigma we find two linearly independent solutions of the homogeneous version of the recurrenceÂ (6.1). To this end, we apply a generalized versionÂ  of
PetkovÅ¡ekâ€™s Hyper algorithmÂ ; we remark that the bases âˆ’72âˆ’Ï€2+12â€‹36+Ï€2Ï€2\frac{-72-\pi^{2}+12\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}}}{\pi^{2}} and âˆ’72+Ï€2+12â€‹36+Ï€2Ï€2-\frac{72+\pi^{2}+12\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}}}{\pi^{2}}of the powers inÂ (6.2) are the roots of the characteristic polynomial that appears in the underlying algorithmÂ . In the next step, we can apply the algorithm given inÂ  to find the particular solution of the recurrenceÂ (6.1) in terms of an indefinite nested double sum over the powers given inÂ (6.2). Then a crucial step for further processing, i.e., for carrying out the estimates in SectionÂ 6.2, is the simplification of the found particular solution. Here again the summation package Sigma can assist; for a survey of the used telescoping algorithms we refer, e.g., toÂ 7. However, with the given limitations of the computer algebra system Mathematica, the underlying implementation does not work properly when dealing with algebraic elements such as 36+Ï€2\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}}. To overcome this situation, we perform the substitution for a new variable bb; note that the inverse substitution is In this way, the technically challenging element 36+Ï€2\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}} vanishes; it simplifies to We remark that such rewritings (also called rationalizing transformations) appear frequently when dealing with nested integrals in the research area of elementary particle physics; for a survey and applications we refer toÂ 7. After this preprocessing step we continue with the sum representation where By construction, if we apply the substitutionÂ (6.5) to S~2â€‹(t)\tilde{S}_{2}(t) one gets S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) back. Repeating the above calculations in this new representation we obtain the improved recurrence We remark that the correctness of the recurrence can be verified by the summand recurrence (not printed here) that is provided by the creative telescoping method.
Solving this recurrence we get now the two linearly independent solutions of the homogeneous version; note that these solutions agree withÂ (6.2) with the substitutions inÂ (6.5), resp.Â (6.4). Most relevant, using Sigma the found particular solution can be simplified to the form for some rational functions R1â€‹(t,u)R_{1}(t,u), R2â€‹(t,u)R_{2}(t,u) and R3â€‹(t,u)R_{3}(t,u) in the variables b,u,tb,u,t. We remark that correctness of the computed solutions can be verified easily by plugging them into the recurrence, carrying out the shift operator on the indefinite nested sums and products, and by finally simplification by performing simple rational function arithmetic. In summary, using Sigma we found two linearly independent solutions of the homogeneous version together with the a particular solution P~â€‹(t,u)\tilde{P}(t,u) of the recurrence itself. Due to the linearly independence of the homogeneous solutions, there exist unique constants c1â€‹(t)c_{1}(t) and c2â€‹(t)c_{2}(t) (free of uu) such that holds for all nonnegative integers tt and uu with tâ‰¥2t\geq 2 and 1â‰¤uâ‰¤tâˆ’21\leq u\leq t-2.
To determine these cjâ€‹(t)c_{j}(t), we consider the two initial values T~â€‹(t,1)\tilde{T}(t,1) and T~â€‹(t,2)\tilde{T}(t,2) which can be simplified with the same technology as above (where tt has taken over the role of uu) to the form By setting u=1,2u=1,2 inÂ (6.6) and solving the underlying system we compute the c1â€‹(t)c_{1}(t) and c2â€‹(t)c_{2}(t) (which we do not print here) and
obtain the desired simplification Finally, we replace in the sum T~â€‹(t,u)\tilde{T}(t,u) by the right-hand side ofÂ (6.7) and apply the substitutionÂ (6.4). This yields an expression that agrees with S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) for all tâ‰¥2t\geq 2 from which one can read of the splittingsÂ (6.15)â€“(6.16) of S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) which in SectionÂ 6.2 are used to obtain the estimateÂ (4.29) in LemmaÂ 4.10. As indicated above, all calculations can be verified independently from the steps of their algorithmic derivations and thus lead to a rigorous proof for the correctness of the simplification. However, all the steps are tedious to handle manually.
To assist such calculations (that are similarly to those that we frequently tackle in particle physicsÂ ),
we provide besides Sigma the package EvaluateMultiSumsÂ 6 which contains all the experience of the Sigmaâ€“developer to carry out these calculations fully automatically. More precisely, after loading the packages
into the computer algebra system Mathematica In:=â€…<<ð’ð¢ð ð¦ðš.ð¦\tt\bf\displaystyle<<Sigma.m

â€¦\displaystyle\tt\dots  the output â€˜â€‹â€˜â€‹â€¦â€‹â€``\dots" that is equivalent toÂ (6.7). Actually, one obtains a slight variant of it that one can transform to the versionÂ (6.7) using the command SigmaReduce; for a concrete application of such a transformation we refer to In[6.1] and In[6.1] below. Using this technology, we focus now on the more involved triple sum S3â€‹(t)S_{3}(t) defined inÂ (4.17). Similarly to S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) we rewrite S3â€‹(t)S_{3}(t) and work with the alternative sum representation When trying to apply the summation tools on these summations, it is reasonable to start with the inner most sum, say Uâ€‹(t,s,u)U(t,s,u). One finds the representation In the next step, one may deal with the second summation using the simplification of Uâ€‹(t,u,s)U(t,u,s). Using Sigma one obtains the recurrence with a right-hand side Râ€‹(t,u)R(t,u) represented in terms of indefinite nested sums too large for being printed here. Solving the homogeneous version of the recurrence gives the two solutions which are closely related to the solutionsÂ (6.2) when dealing with S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t). Indeed, the algorithmÂ  (and the generalized versionÂ  implemented in Sigma) asks again for the roots of the same polynomialÂ (6.3) that establishes the powers involving the algebraic element
36+Ï€2\sqrt{36+\pi^{2}}. Thus using the same rationalizing transformationÂ (6.4) that we used above for the S2â€‹(t)S_{2}(t) one obtains homogeneous solutions that are free of any algebraic elements. This suggests to reconsider the sum S3â€‹(t)S_{3}(t) by applying first the substitutionÂ (6.4) leading to i.e., S3â€‹(t)S_{3}(t) equals to S~3â€‹(t)\tilde{S}_{3}(t) after applying the inverse transformationÂ (6.5). To this end, we insert the double sum In[ref]5:=â€…ð“~=âˆ‘ð¬=ðŸŽð­âˆ’ð¢âˆ’ðŸ(âˆ’ð¬âˆ’ð®)ð®â€‹(ðŸðŸâˆ’ð¬âˆ’ð®)ðŸ+ð¬+ð®(ðŸ+ð¬+ðŸâ€‹ð®)!â€‹âˆ‘ð«=ðŸŽð­âˆ’ð®âˆ’ð¬âˆ’ðŸ(âˆ’ðŸ)ð«â€‹(ð›ðŸðŸâˆ’ð›ðŸ)ð«â€‹(âˆ’ðŸðŸâˆ’ð«âˆ’ðŸâˆ’ð«âˆ’ð¬+ð­âˆ’ð®);\tt\bf\displaystyle\tilde{T}=\sum_{s=0}^{t-i-2}\frac{(-s-u)_{u}\big{(}\frac{1}{2}-s-u\big{)}_{1+s+u}}{(1+s+2u)!}\sum_{r=0}^{t-u-s-1}(-1)^{r}\big{(}\tfrac{b^{2}}{1-b^{2}}\big{)}^{r}\left(\begin{smallmatrix}-\frac{1}{2}-r\\

-\frac{(-3+2t)\big{(}-1+2b^{2}t\big{)}\big{(}(-1+b)^{1+2u}-(1+b)^{1+2u}\big{)}(-1+b)^{-u}(1+b)^{-u}\big{(}\frac{5}{2}-t\big{)}_{-1+t}}{4b^{2}(1+2u)t!}\newline
+\frac{b(-3+2t)(-1+2t)(-1+b)^{-1-u}(1+b)^{1+u}\big{(}\frac{5}{2}-t\big{)}_{-1+t}}{2t(1+2u)}\sum_{i=1}^{u}\frac{(-1+b)^{i}(1+b)^{-i}(-t)_{i}}{(-1+i+t)!}\newline
+\frac{3\big{(}(-1+b)^{1+2u}-(1+b)^{1+2u}\big{)}(-1+b)^{-t-u}(1+b)^{-t-u}}{4b^{2}(1+2u)}\sum_{i=1}^{t}\frac{(-1+b)^{i}(1+b)^{i}\big{(}\frac{5}{2}-i\big{)}_{-1+i}}{i!}\newline
-\frac{b(-3+2t)(-1+2t)(-1+b)^{1+u}(1+b)^{-1-u}\big{(}\frac{5}{2}-t\big{)}_{-1+t}}{2t(1+2u)}\sum_{i=1}^{u}\frac{(-1+b)^{-i}(1+b)^{i}(-t)_{i}}{(-1+i+t)!}  In order to represent the expression in terms of the products u!,(âˆ’t)uu!,(-t)_{u} and t!,(t+u)!,(1/2âˆ’t)tt!,(t+u)!,(1/2-t)_{t}, one may use the following commands: In:=â€…ðœð¥ð¨ð¬ðžðð…ð¨ð«ð¦â€‹ð“~=ð’ð¢ð ð¦ðšð‘ðžðð®ðœðžâ€‹[ðœð¥ð¨ð¬ðžðð…ð¨ð«ð¦â€‹ð“~,ð®,ð“ð¨ð°ðžð«â†’{ð®!,(âˆ’ð­)ð®}]\tt\bf\displaystyle closedForm\tilde{T}=SigmaReduce[closedForm\tilde{T},u,Tower\to\{u!,(-t)_{u}\}] In:=â€…ðœð¥ð¨ð¬ðžðð…ð¨ð«ð¦â€‹ð“~=ð’ð¢ð ð¦ðšð‘ðžðð®ðœðžâ€‹[ðœð¥ð¨ð¬ðžðð…ð¨ð«ð¦â€‹ð“~,ð­,ð“ð¨ð°ðžð«â†’{ð­!,(ð­+ð®)!,(ðŸ/ðŸâˆ’ð­)ð­}]\tt\bf\displaystyle closedForm\tilde{T}=SigmaReduce[closedForm\tilde{T},t,Tower\to\{t!,(t+u)!,(1/2-t)_{t}\}] Out=â€…
((âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž+(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž)ðŸ¸â€‹(ðŸ·+ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž)â€‹(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðš+ðšžâˆ’ðŸ·â€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðš+ðšžâˆ’ðŸ·âˆ’((âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž+(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž)â€‹(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ·âˆ’ðšžâ€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ·âˆ’ðšžâ€‹(ðŸ·ðŸ¸âˆ’ðš)ðšðŸ¸â€‹(ðŸ·+ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž)â€‹ðš!+(ðšâˆ’ðšž)â€‹(ðŸ¸â€‹ðš‹ðŸ¸â€‹ðšâˆ’ðš‹ðŸ¸âˆ’ðŸ¸â€‹ðš+ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž+ðŸ¸)â€‹(ðŸ·ðŸ¸âˆ’ðš)ðšâ€‹(âˆ’ðš)ðšžðšâ€‹(ðŸ¸â€‹ðšâˆ’ðŸ·)â€‹(ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž+ðŸ·)â€‹(ðš+ðšž)!+((âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž+(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ¸â€‹ðšžâˆ’ðš‹â€‹(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž+ðš‹â€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž)ðŸ¸â€‹(ðŸ·+ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž)â€‹(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðš+ðšžâ€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðš+ðšžâ€‹âˆ‘ðš’=ðŸ·ðš(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðš’â€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðš’â€‹(ðŸ·ðŸ¸âˆ’ðš’)ðš’(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðŸ¸â€‹ðš’)â€‹ðš’!âˆ’ðš‹â€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ·+ðšžâ€‹(ðŸ·ðŸ¸âˆ’ðš)ðš(ðŸ·+ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž)â€‹(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðšžâ€‹âˆ‘ðš’=ðŸ·ðšž(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðš’â€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)âˆ’ðš’â€‹(âˆ’ðš)ðš’(ðš’+ðš)!âˆ’ðš‹â€‹(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðŸ·+ðšžâ€‹(ðŸ·ðŸ¸âˆ’ðš)ðš(ðŸ·+ðŸ¸â€‹ðšž)â€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðšžâ€‹âˆ‘ðš’=ðŸ·ðšž(âˆ’ðŸ·+ðš‹)âˆ’ðš’â€‹(ðŸ·+ðš‹)ðš’â€‹(âˆ’ðš)ðš’(ðš’+ðš)!\displaystyle\tt\frac{\big{(}(-1+b)^{2u}+(1+b)^{2u}\big{)}}{2(1+2u)(-1+b)^{t+u-1}(1+b)^{t+u-1}}-\frac{\big{(}(-1+b)^{2u}+(1+b)^{2u}\big{)}(-1+b)^{1-u}(1+b)^{1-u}\big{(}\frac{1}{2}-t\big{)}_{t}}{2(1+2u)t!}\newline
